articles.headline: U.S. and Mexico Sign Trucking Deal
articles.snippet: A tariff deal carries out a crucial provision of NAFTA after 17 years of bickering.
articles.abstract: A tariff deal carries out a crucial provision of NAFTA after 17 years of bickering.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mexican truckers will be able to carry goods deep into the United States, and vice versa, under a deal signed Wednesday in Mexico City to keep a 17-year-old promise.

articles.headline: Wireless, Not Wimpy, Speakers
articles.snippet: There have always been compromises with speakers that do away with wires, but a new system solves many of those problems.
articles.abstract: There have always been compromises with speakers that do away with wires, but a new system solves many of those problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Modern technology is great and all, but it’s still studded with pain points. Just ask anyone who’s ever tried to set up a home network, to send a video by e-mail or to maintain a phone call driving down I-95.

articles.headline: Spain Confronts Decades of Pain Over Lost Babies
articles.snippet: An investigation into the disappearances of newborns from 1950 to 1990 involves allegations of abductions and the existence of criminal networks.
articles.abstract: An investigation into the disappearances of newborns from 1950 to 1990 involves allegations of abductions and the existence of criminal networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEVILLE, Spain — Prodded by grieving parents, Spanish judges are investigating hundreds of charges that infants were abducted and sold for adoption over a 40-year period. What may have begun as political retaliation for leftist families during the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco appears to have mutated into a trafficking business in which doctors, nurses and even nuns colluded with criminal networks.

articles.headline: L.A. Prepares for Worst and Hopes for Best in Freeway Shutdown
articles.snippet: A freeway-widening project has drawn on the likes of Lady Gaga to help warn drivers away for July 16 and 17.
articles.abstract: A freeway-widening project has drawn on the likes of Lady Gaga to help warn drivers away for July 16 and 17.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — You would think that Los Angeles, of all places, would know how to handle a catastrophe.

articles.headline: Building Boom in China Stirs Fears of Debt Overload
articles.snippet: Frenzied construction in cities like Wuhan belies signs that development financed with borrowing by local governments could undermine China’s economic progress.
articles.abstract: Frenzied construction in cities like Wuhan belies signs that development financed with borrowing by local governments could undermine China’s economic progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — In the seven years it will take New York City to build a two-mile leg of its long-awaited Second Avenue subway line, this city of nine million people in central China plans to complete an entirely new subway system, with nearly 140 miles of track.

articles.headline: Obama to Push for Wider Deal With G.O.P. on Deficit Cuts
articles.snippet: President Obama, who will meet with the bipartisan leadership of Congress on Thursday, wants to move well beyond the $2 trillion in savings sought earlier.
articles.abstract: President Obama, who will meet with the bipartisan leadership of Congress on Thursday, wants to move well beyond the $2 trillion in savings sought earlier.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Heading into a crucial negotiating session on a budget deal on Thursday, President Obama has raised his sights and wants to strike a far-reaching agreement on cutting the federal deficit as Speaker John A. Boehner has signaled new willingness to bargain on revenues.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Mark Landler

articles.headline: The Murdoch Style, Under Pressure
articles.snippet: Line-skirting has always been part of doing business for Rupert Murdoch, but a voice-mail hacking scandal poses a new type of threat to News Corporation’s image.
articles.abstract: Line-skirting has always been part of doing business for Rupert Murdoch, but a voice-mail hacking scandal poses a new type of threat to News Corporation’s image.
articles.lead_paragraph: Risk-taking and line-skirting have always been just one more cost of doing business for Rupert Murdoch.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Scandal Shifts Britain’s Media and Political Landscape
articles.snippet: An arrest seems imminent for The News of the World’s once politically influential former editor after the Murdochs announced plans to shut down the tabloid.
articles.abstract: An arrest seems imminent for The News of the World’s once politically influential former editor after the Murdochs announced plans to shut down the tabloid.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s media and political landscape shifted Thursday as the powerful Murdoch family summarily announced plans to shut down the disgraced mass-circulation tabloid at the center of a deepening scandal over journalistic malfeasance, and arrest seemed imminent for the paper’s once politically influential former editor.

articles.headline: Still ‘Far Apart’ on Debt, 2 Sides Will Seek Broader Cuts
articles.snippet: G.O.P. leaders and President Obama emerged from talks with a consensus to aim for the biggest possible deal — one resulting in up to $4 trillion in savings.
articles.abstract: G.O.P. leaders and President Obama emerged from talks with a consensus to aim for the biggest possible deal — one resulting in up to $4 trillion in savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, convening budget talks at the White House on Thursday, said Republicans and Democrats were still “far apart” but expressed confidence they could agree on an ambitious deal to prevent the government from defaulting on its debt.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Carl Hulse
